response.answer_text: Yes. Thomas Jefferson was eager to get rid of Aaron Burr, his first Vice President, and switched to George Clinton for the election of 1804. Andrew Jackson came to despise John Calhoun, his first Vice President, and dumped him for Martin van Buren in 1832. Abraham Lincoln replaced Hannibal Hamlin with Andrew Johnson in 1864. Ulysses Grant replaced Schuyler Colfax with Henry Wilson in 1872. In other cases the president switched to a different vice-presidential candidate because his first Vice President had died in office. James Madison, e.g., started off with George Clinton, but ran for a second term with Elbridge Gerry (after whom the gerrymander is named). Other presidents campaigned for re-election with a different vice-presidential running mate, but were defeated. Gerald Ford dumped Nelson Rockefeller in 1976 for Bob Dole, but lost to Jimmy Carter.

Thomas Jefferson (Aaron Burr [fled the country after killing Alexander Hamilton), George Clinton) James Madison (George Clinton [died in office], Elbridge Gerry [died in office]) Andrew Jackson (John C Calhoun [resigned], Martin Van Buren) Abraham Lincoln (Hannibal Hamlin, Andrew Johnson) Ulysses S Grant (Schuyler Colfax, Henry Wilson) Grover Cleveland (Thomas Henricks [died in office], Adlai Stevenson) note—Cleveland’s two terms were not consecutive. William McKinley (Garret Hobart [died in office], Theodore Roosevelt) Franklin D Roosevelt (John Nance Garner, Henry A Wallace, Harry S Truman) Richard Nixon (Spiro Agnew [Agnew was running mate for both terms—Agnew resigned during his second term), Gerald Ford)
